newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Australian bonds stand firm pre-key US data.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Australian bonds stand firm pre-key US data.

text.p: The Australian debt market closed firm after its busiest day of the year so far as it continued to convince itself that the Reserve Bank will ease policy again.

March bill futures struck a new contract high of 94.34, more than discounting a 25 basis point reduction in the current 6.0 percent official interest rate, despite another attempt by the RBA to dampen speculation about a potential policy change.

For the second day in a row the central bank made a rare move in responding to market speculation that an easing was imminent, and dispelling talk that an emergency meeting had been called in January.
"I think that's it until the board meet on February 4, but people just seem to want to buy the market, and willing to take the risk on what could happen in the States," said one trader.

The U.S. releases it December PPI later today and non-farm payrolls for the same month on Friday, which are seen as key indicators as to whether the Federal Reserve will tighten monetary policy in the neart-term.
Traders said that the U.S. has probably done enough on the downside on the long bond in fearing the worst from the data.
U.S. Treausries fell for a third consecutive session on Wednesday in New York.

Local long-dated bonds finally joined in the firm tone of the short-end and made a substantial tightening against other dollar bloc bonds. The trend was fuelled by the break back below 100 basis points on the Australian/U.S. 10-year bond spread, traders said.
